1.text: Don’t boast about tomorrow; for you don’t know what a day may bring forth.

2.text: Let another man praise you, and not your own mouth; a stranger, and not your own lips.

3.text: A stone is heavy, and sand is a burden; but a fool’s provocation is heavier than both.

4.text: Wrath is cruel, and anger is overwhelming; but who is able to stand before jealousy?

5.text: Better is open rebuke than hidden love.

6.text: Faithful are the wounds of a friend; although the kisses of an enemy are profuse.

7.text: A full soul loathes a honeycomb; but to a hungry soul, every bitter thing is sweet.

8.text: As a bird that wanders from her nest, so is a man who wanders from his home.

9.text: Perfume and incense bring joy to the heart; so does earnest counsel from a man’s friend.

10.text: Don’t forsake your friend and your father’s friend. Don’t go to your brother’s house in the day of your disaster: better is a neighbor who is near than a distant brother.

11.text: Be wise, my son, and bring joy to my heart, then I can answer my tormentor.

12.text: A prudent man sees danger and takes refuge; but the simple pass on, and suffer for it.

13.text: Take his garment when he puts up collateral for a stranger. Hold it for a wayward woman!

14.text: He who blesses his neighbor with a loud voice early in the morning, it will be taken as a curse by him.

15.text: A continual dropping on a rainy day and a contentious wife are alike:

16.text: restraining her is like restraining the wind, or like grasping oil in his right hand.

17.text: Iron sharpens iron; so a man sharpens his friend’s countenance.

18.text: Whoever tends the fig tree shall eat its fruit. He who looks after his master shall be honored.

19.text: As water reflects a face, so a man’s heart reflects the man.

20.text: Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied; and a man’s eyes are never satisfied.

21.text: The crucible is for silver, and the furnace for gold; but man is refined by his praise.

22.text: Though you grind a fool in a mortar with a pestle along with grain, yet his foolishness will not be removed from him.

23.text: Know well the state of your flocks, and pay attention to your herds:

24.text: for riches are not forever, nor does even the crown endure to all generations.

25.text: The hay is removed, and the new growth appears, the grasses of the hills are gathered in.

26.text: The lambs are for your clothing, and the goats are the price of a field.

27.text: There will be plenty of goats’ milk for your food, for your family’s food, and for the nourishment of your servant girls.
